SourceText: *Cooking with Maths*
Cooking can help your boy or girl start learning maths!
üíö Invite your girl or boy to help you cook for your family, or to choose something they would like to cook
üçÖ Ask your boy or girl to count different ingredients. Help them if it‚Äôs difficult!
üîü Help your girl or boy to understand adding and subtracting quantities
üìù Encourage your boy or girl to recognise numbers on packaging
üëÄ Ask your girl or boy about the different sizes of ingredients - e.g. which is bigger/biggest?
üîÑ Think about when you will cook together again! You can also practise understanding numbers and quantities during other activities like shopping or building/making things
*Following Instructions*
üëÇ Play a game in which your boy or girl listens to and tries to remember strings of instructions.
This will be useful in school, at home, and later in life!
Start with just one instruction using an object in your home. For example ‚Äútouch the red ball‚Äù üî¥
Slowly add more instructions (e.g ‚Äúthen pick up the cup ‚òï), but tell your girl or boy that they can only start once you‚Äôve finished giving the instructions.
See how many your boy or girl can follow without forgetting!
üîÑ Now swap roles! It‚Äôs your boy or girl‚Äôs turn to give you instructions! They can use the same objects if they want.
You can also try this game with a group of girls and boys! Make sure they take turns :)
*One-on-One Time*
üíö Spending time just with your girl or boy and taking an interest in them can improve your relationship.
üëÄ When your boy or girl is playing alone or occupying themselves quietly, join them and show interest in what they are doing.
üëÇAsk questions about their activity, and listen to them.
Let your girl or boy lead the activity, follow them to build their confidence and autonomy üòÉ.
üëÄ Say what you see - describing everything and supporting your boy‚Äôs or girl‚Äôs actions.
Be positive, praise your girl or boy, and enjoy spending this time with them üòÉüíö
*Playtime with Books*
üìñ Book sharing will help your boy or girl learn and is a fun, playful activity to spend quality time together.
‚è∞ Choose a time when you won‚Äôt be disturbed, and try to stop any distractions - e.g. turn off the TV and put away phones.
üìñ If your girl or boy wants to choose a book, that‚Äôs fine, otherwise choose for them.
üíö Sit close together and follow your boy or girl attention and lead.
Point at things, name and repeat words. Help them to learn more about what interests them in the book üëÄ
If there are words or numbers in the book, ask and help your girl or boy recognise letters numbers, and simple words üí°.
Link things in the books to your child's life, and use words about emotions and talk about them! üòÉ.
üîÑ If possible, start a regular routine to read together when your girl or boy isn‚Äôt too tired or hungry.
Reading together is one of the best ways to help your boy or girl learn and prepare for success in school! üéì
üìñ Book sharing will help your girl or boy learn and is a fun, playful activity to spend quality time together
‚è∞ Choose a time when you won‚Äôt be disturbed, and try to stop any distractions - e.g. turn off the TV and put away phones
üìñ If your boy or girl wants to choose a book, that‚Äôs fine, otherwise choose for them
üíö Sit close together and follow your girl or boy attention and lead
Link things in the books to your child's life, and use words about emotions and talk about them! üòÉ
üîÑ If possible, start a regular routine to read together when your girl or boy isn‚Äôt too tired or hungry
*I Spy!*
üëÄ I spy is a fun game to play with your girl or boy that will help them learn about letters and words!
Choose an object or a thing around you, and don‚Äôt tell your boy or girl what it is. It should be something that your boy or girl knows the word for. For example ‚Äúball‚Äù ‚öΩ
üëÄ Then say ‚ÄúI spy with my little eye, something beginning with *and then say the first letter of the word* which in this case is ‚Äúb‚Äù

Your girl or boy should look around and guess what the object is. When they guess it right, praise them and swap roles! If they can‚Äôt get it, give them some clues, like ‚Äúit‚Äôs round‚Äù or ‚Äúit‚Äôs black and white‚Äù. ‚úÖ

Play this game with as many objects as possible and as many different letters! Help your boy or girl to learn about the different letters and sounds in words. This will help them learn to read at home and school. üéì
*Categorising and Organising*
Help your girl or boy to learn by sorting objects and things! üîµüî∑
Your boy or girl will learn by understanding how things fit and group together (eg, bear = animal, mango = fruit, blue = colour) üß∏
Find a book with different pictures and help your girl or boy to find things in a particular category (e.g. ‚ÄúFind all of the animals‚Äù) üëÄ
Find *safe* objects in the house, get your boy or girl to group them by colour, size, or types of object (cups, plates). Then make more complicated categories (e.g. small cups, big cups) ‚òï
üîÑ You can play the categorising game anywhere! Just look around and ask your girl or boy to find things from the category you say!
*What Letter is This?*
Playing games with letters can help your boy or girl learn the alphabet and how letters are put together to make words.
üìù Write a letter on a piece of card or paper (e.g. ‚Äúp‚Äù)
üëÇ Say the letter out loud and ask your girl or boy to say it too!
Ask your boy or girl to say some words that begin with the letter ‚Äúp‚Äù, give them clues like ‚ÄúWhat starts with ‚Äúp‚Äù? Plant‚Ä¶ What else? üå±
üëÄ Ask your girl or boy to look for objects in your house that begin with a letter (eg ‚Äúp‚Äù for plate). Help them find things.
üîÑ Try a new letter every day!
*Riddles Help Boys and Girls Learn*
Riddles and puzzles are a fun way to build thinking skills! üí°
Do you remember any riddles from your childhood? If you can‚Äôt then make one up, they can be very simple! üòÉ
Like ‚ÄúWhat can you see at night but not in the day‚Äù Answer: ‚ÄúThe moon‚Äù üåô
If your girl or boy is finding them difficult, try an easy one like: ‚ÄúWhat is round, bouncy and can be thrown or kicked?‚Äù Answer: ‚ÄúA ball‚Äù ‚öΩ
Your boy or girl can also try making riddles! üí°
You can have fun with riddles anywhere at any time - like traveling on a bus, walking to school or in a car üöó
*What's New?*
Learning is fun! üéì
‚ùì Ask your girl or boy to think of a new, fun skill you could learn together.
For example: keeping a ball in the air with your foot, juggling, making soup, moonwalking, whistling, saying the alphabet backwards, learning all the states in Mexico.
üîÑ Take turns trying out the new skill. Make sure to praise each other and learn and play together!
üíõ Approach learning the skill in a kind and fun way, and do not judge your boy or girl or yourself for your ability in the skill.
üòÉ Once you have mastered the skill, choose another skill to learn together.
*Make up a Story*
Creating stories together is a great way to have fun with imagination - and to build your girl or boy‚Äôs creativity! üìñ

5Ô∏è‚É£ With your boy or girl, come up with 5 words to use. They can be any words you want! For example: banana, spaceship, fish, water, painting, cooking, wedding. If you need to remember them, write them clearly on a paper with your girl or boy.

üéÇ Start your story with, ‚ÄúOnce upon a time, there was a‚Ä¶‚Äù and use one of the words from the list in the first part. For example, ‚ÄúOnce upon a time, there was a family who worked on a *banana* farm.‚Äù
üìù Let your boy or girl make up the next part using another word from the list.
üîÑ Take turns until you have used all the words and created a story.
üîî Be creative and do not tell your girl or boy what to say. It does not need to be a real story to be fun!
üéÅ Ask your boy or girl what their favourite part of the story was, and tell them yours!
*Playing with Clothes*
üí°Help your girl or boy use their fingers, talk about clothes, and organise them!
Help your boy or girl exercise their fingers by showing them how buttons and zips work on clothes, and letting them practise using them! üëã
üîµ Talk about the colours of clothes! Ask your girl or boy to pick a colour and talk about all the things that are that colour: ‚ÄúWhat are all the things we can think of that are blue?‚Äù
üòÉ Encourage your boy or girl to help you sort clothes into piles for each family member.
*Playing with Vegetables*
üå± Help your girl or boy learn by thinking and talking about vegetables!
üçÖ Mix together 2-3 different ingredients of your choice (like onions, tomatoes and corn example). Say: ‚ÄúHelp me sort these vegetables into piles?‚Äù Try sorting them by size.
üòÉ Remind me!
Talk about your child‚Äôs experiences. Ask questions and wait for answers. Follow your child‚Äôs interests.

‚ÄúCan you help me remember what is at the market?‚Äù ‚ÄúDo they sell carrots at the market?‚Äù ‚ÄúDo they sell anything yellow at the market?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat else do they sell?‚Äù ‚ÄúCan you think of other things they sell?‚Äù
üí°Can you think of something similar?
Say: We are going to think of some things that are similar or different from what I tell you. So listen carefully!‚Äù
Here is a tomato. Can you think of something else that is red like a tomato? üçÖ
Can you think of something else that is round like a tomato? ‚öΩ
*Animals*
üß∏ Active animals: Take turns with @fields.child_nickname doing animal actions: Hop like a frog, stretch like a cat, run like a dog, slither like a snake, flap like a bird
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: üß∏ Active animals: Take turns with your child doing animal actions: Hop like a frog, stretch like a cat, run like a dog, slither like a snake, flap like a bird
üí°All the animals we can think of - think about groups of animals!
What are all the animals we can think of that have feathers?
What are all the animals we can think of that eat plants? üå±
What are all the animals we can think of that lay eggs?
üòÉ Counting rabbits
üîü Find 10 rocks and put them in a line, tell your girl or boy that they are rabbits!
Ask them to count the rabbits!
Put the rabbits into 2 equal piles. Ask your boy or girl to give you 3 rabbits. Say ‚ÄúIf you give me 3, how many rabbits do you have?‚Äù
*Active Counting*
üëã Clap, hop, jump: Play the following game with @fields.child_nickname. Make it active!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Clap hands 1 time. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Clap hands 2 times.
1Ô∏è‚É£ Jump 1 time. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Jump 2 times.
1Ô∏è‚É£ Hop 1 time.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Hop 3 times.
üí°Can you hop, then jump, then clap?
üèÜ Can you clap twice, jump once, and hop three times?
üëã Clap, hop, jump: Play the following game with your child. Make it active!
üí°Remembering Instructions
Take turns playing a game where you give 2-3 instructions that the other person has to remember to follow. Make sure physical movement is included!
For example:
Hop twice, turn around.
Jump to the kitchen, pick up a spoon, then run back. ‚úÖ
*Thinking Games*
‚ùó Mama/Daddy says! Play this game of giving instructions:
Mama/daddy says touch your head. Mama/daddy says open your mouth. Mama/daddy says turn around. Mama/daddy says touch your knees. Mama/daddy says jump twice. Mama/daddy says jump, then clap and sit.
üîµ üî¥Blue-Red - now play this game!
If I say touch something blue, you need to touch something red. If I say touch something red, you need to touch something blue.
üëÇ Go and stop: Play the game with @fields.child_nickname
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Say: When I say ‚Äústop‚Äù, we freeze. When I say ‚Äúgo‚Äù, we can walk again.
Once @fields.child_nickname is familiar with the game, @fields.child_nickname will lead.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: üëÇ Go and stop: Play the game with your child
Once your child is familiar with the game, your child will lead.
*Games with Pictures!*
üëÇ Making up a story from an image
For example, say: We are going to make up a story about this picture. I can start. This little girl is feeling very excited today. Why do you think she is feeling excited?
üòÉ She is holding her bag and has a big smile. Where do you think she is going?
üëÄ Can you point to it?
Using a book or a magazine, or anything with pictures, say:
I am going to describe something on the page and you need to guess what it is and point to it. For example, ‚ÄúI see something that is [green and moves slowly].
Can you guess what it is?‚Äù üíö
*Shapes Everywhere!*
üì∫ Squares, squares everywhere
üëÄ Draw squares in the sand or dirt. Make some bigger and some smaller.
Tell @fields.child_nickname, ‚Äúthis is a square.‚Äù
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Ask your girl or boy to try to draw a square. Hold your boy‚Äôs or girl‚Äôs hand to help if this is hard.
Look for things around the home or outdoors that are the same shape.
Now do the same with circles! üî¥
Tell your child, ‚Äúthis is a square.‚Äù
*Story Telling*
üí° Let‚Äôs make a story!
Say: We are going to make up a story. I will start then you will help me continue it.
‚è∞ ‚ÄùOnce upon a time there was‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat happened next?‚ÄùüëÄ
‚ÄúWhat happened after that?‚Äù
üëÇ Tell me the story!
Say to @fields.child_nickname: ‚ÄúI have a book here that we have read before. Can you remember the story and tell it to me just by looking at the pictures?‚Äù
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: üëÄ Show your girl or boy pictures in the book. Ask your boy or girl what is happening in the pictures and what happens next.
Say to your child: ‚ÄúI have a book here that we have read before. Can you remember the story and tell it to me just by looking at the pictures?‚Äù
*I'm a Writer!*
üìù Have fun being creative with writing!
You and @fields.child_nickname can have fun writing with a pencil and paper, or with a stick and the sand!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: If your girl or boy doesn‚Äôt know how to write letters, encourage them to draw shapes, and try to copy the shapes of letters. üîµ‚ñ∂Ô∏è
When they are more confident, encourage them to write letters and even words. üòÉStart showing them how to write their name and other important words for them, like mom, ball or milk.
Show them the simple things that you write - like shopping lists! Show them the words and each of the letters. Let them try to copy the words! üìñ
You and your child can have fun writing with a pencil and paper, or with a stick and the sand!
*A Friendly Chat*
Talk to your girl or boy about something that they are interested in! üòÉ
üíö Spending quality time with your boy or girl and talking to them every day is a good way to develop a strong relationship.

‚öΩ An easy way to start talking to your girl or boy is to ask them about something they are interested in, for example you could talk about topics such as: sports, books, movies, friends, music, celebrities, or school.
üëÇ You may not find everything your boy or girl shares to be interesting, but it‚Äôs important to show enthusiasm and an eagerness to learn.
*Get Active*
Exercise is a great way to spend time together and it is so good for your health. üå± Find a sport or exercise that both you and your girl or boy want to do and try it out together!
‚è∞ Even walking for 10 minutes a day is good for you.
‚öΩ Together you can walk, run, play soccer, swim, dance, or do any other sport..
üèÜ Together, think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns being the coach? Can there be a small, free reward, like getting to decide the next activity?
üåà Exercise becomes easier and more enjoyable the more you do it.
üîÑ If you or your girl or boy do not like the first exercise you pick, try a new exercise.
*Pass the Ball*
Games are a great, fun way to spend time with your family!
3Ô∏è‚É£ This game is best with at least 3 people.
‚öΩ Find a ball to play. If you cannot find a ball, choose an item you can safely throw around. For example, a bottle cap or a plastic cup.
‚û°Ô∏è Start in a circle and pass the ball around.

üëã Start throwing the ball in new directions (up, down, straight, curved, rolling on the ground) and with different forces (hard, soft, medium). You can bounce the ball, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.
‚ú® When everyone gets good at catching the ball, you can start moving around the room, still passing the ball.
‚≠ê Can you throw the ball under the leg? Behind the back? Over your head? Block a pass? Have fun with it!
*Active Songs*
üòÉ Young boys and girls love physical games! But they need reminders about how to play üí°
üéµ Songs with movements are fun and active and give instructions on how to move!
Sing songs to @fields.child_nickname or a group of girls and boys in which they have to:
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: ‚úÖ Start and stop ‚ùå
‚¨áÔ∏è Slow down and speed up ‚¨ÜÔ∏è
Sing songs to your child or a group of girls and boys in which they have to:
*Follow the Leader!*
‚≠ê Choose someone to be the leader (tip: start with an adult like yourself)
üòÉ Other players line up behind the leader. The leader moves around in any way they like!
üèÅ They can run, jump, crawl, walk on tiptoe, and any other way they want!
üëÄ The other players must copy what the leader does, and the leader can change movements at any time.
üîÑ Players take turns being the leader!
*Be the Narrator*
üëÄ Say what your girl or boy is doing while they are playing
üëÇ This will help them learn the words to describe their actions.
üòÉ You can do it in a simple way, or in a silly way like a sports commentator, a news presenter, or a game show host
üí° Ask questions like ‚Äúwhat will you do next?‚Äù or ‚ÄúI see you want to put the ball in the jar. Is there another way to do that?‚Äù
*Be an Artist!*
üìù Give @fields.child_nickname some paper and a pen or pencil, or some different pens or pencils.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: üòÉ Let your girl or boy draw whatever they want to!
üëÄ Ask questions about what they are drawing, the size of the thing they are drawing, and the colours they are using.
üèÜ If possible, put your boy or girl‚Äôs picture up on the wall when they are finished. Give praise to your girl or boy!
üìù Give your child some paper and a pen or pencil, or some different pens or pencils.
*Be an Expert in Emotions!*
üìù Create an album of the six emotions with @fields.child_nickname: happy, sad, angry, disgusted, surprised, afraid.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Draw, cut-out pictures from magazines, or take photos of family members showing different emotions.
Label each emotion and add words about how each family member feels those emotions.
Put the album in a spot everyone agrees on, and use it throughout the day to show how the family is feeling. For example, after school, everyone can pin the emotion they‚Äôre experiencing.

Feel free to add new feelings as they come up. If someone doesn‚Äôt know what they are feeling, help them identify it by exploring how it feels in their body. Try together to find a new word for that emotion.
This can help everyone in the family become experts in understanding themselves and be aware of what their bodies need.
üìù Create an album of the six emotions with your child: happy, sad, angry, disgusted, surprised, afraid.
